Continuing the critically-acclaimed Britannia music series 
for BBC Four, this documentary tells the story of the emergence 
and evolution of the British music festival through the mavericks, 
dreamers and dropouts who have produced, enjoyed and sometimes 
fought for them over the last 50 years.

The film traces the ebb and flow of British festival culture 
from jazz beginnings at Beaulieu in the late 50s through to the 
Isle of Wight festivals at the end of the 60s, early Glastonbury 
and one-off commercial festivals like 1972's Bickershaw, the 
free festivals of the 70s and 80s and on through the extended 
rave at Castlemorton in 1992 to the contemporary resurgence in 
festivals like Glastonbury, Isle of Wight and Reading in the 
last decade.

Sam Bridger's film explores the central tension between the 
people's desire to come together, dance to the music and build 
temporary communities and the desire of the state, the councils 
and the locals to police these often unruly gatherings.

At the heart of the documentary is an ongoing argument about 
British freedom and shifts in the political, musical and cultural 
landscape set to a wonderful soundtrack of 50 years of great popular 
music which takes in trad jazz, Traffic, Roy Harper, 
the Grateful Dead, Hawkwind, Orbital and much more.

Featuring rare archive and interviews with Michael Eavis, 
Richard Thompson, Acker Bilk, Terry Reid, the Levellers, Billy Bragg, 
John Giddings, Melvin Benn, Roy Harper, Nik Turner, Peter Jenner, 
Orbital, amongst others.
